Two Fe(II) complexes bearing chelating monoanionic [N,N]− pyridylamido ligands with bulky 2,6-dialkylphenyl substituents at both the amido and the ortho-pyridine moieties were synthesized and characterized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the formation of heteroleptic mononuclear [N,N]FeIIN(SiMe3)2 three-coordinated complexes. The two complexes were tested as catalysts for the Ring Opening Polymerization (ROP) of l-lactide (L-LA) and ε-caprolactone (CL) in the presence of 1 equiv. of alcohol co-initiator, resulting in high activity under both mild conditions (in solution at room temperature and low monomer/catalyst ratio) and more industrially relevant conditions (higher temperature and high monomer/catalyst ratio). The high activity and living character of the Fe(II) catalysts allowed the synthesis of stereo-multiblock polylactides by one-pot sequential addition of l-LA, d-LA and rac-LA at room temperature and in short reaction times, as well as the synthesis of di-block PCL-b-PLLA and three-block PLLA-b-PCL-b-PLLA copolymers by a similar approach. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ROP Iron catalyst PLA PCL Block copolymer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aliphatic polyesters have emerged as highly desirable targets of a sustainable polymer industry in a circular economy: indeed, many polymers of this class can be obtained from renewable feedstocks and undergo biodegradation [1]. Aliphatic polyesters can be produced by polycondensation of diols with diacids (or diesters), or hydroxyl acids. These step growth polymerization processes, however, are difficult to control (particularly with respect to polymer molecular weight, which is often quite low), and are usually energy-intensive at the stage of water or alcohol removal (necessary to push conversion). Therefore, the ring opening polymerization (ROP) of lactones is generally preferred: e. g., the industrial production of polylactide (PLA), by far the most important polymer in this class with a current market of 300 ktons/year, is based on the ROP of l-lactide (L-LA) promoted by Sn(II) 2-ethyl-hexanoate (Sn(Oct)2) in a continuous solvent-free process operating at high temperatures (≈ 190 °C) [2]. Sn(Oct)2 is cheap, reasonably active and does not promote significant l-LA epimerization under the process conditions, although the occurrence of transesterification reactions results in broadening of the polymer molecular weight distribution. In the last two decades, many studies have addressed the search of alternative catalysts, mainly driven by (i) the concern for the presence of cytotoxic Sn residues in commercial PLA for medical and food packaging applications, and (ii) the aim to achieve fine tuning of chain microstructure and architecture to control and expand the properties envelope of aliphatic polyesters, ranging from large volume commodities to specialties for medicine or pharmacology. Thus, on one hand, a huge number of catalysts based on non-toxic metals, such as magnesium, calcium, zinc, aluminum, bearing a variety of ancillary ligands, including β-diketiminates, bis(phenolates), phenoxyimines, guanidines, alkoxides, etc., have been tested [3] and, on the other hand, suitable catalysts operating either via an enantiomorphic site or a chain end mechanism of steric control have been reported to afford a variety of polymer stereochemical structures, e. g., isotactic, syndiotactic, heterotactic, stereogradient and stereoblock PLA's [4–10]. Stereo-multiblock PLA's have been also produced by via one-pot sequential addition of different lactide isomers using extremely active and living Mg and Zn catalysts [11–15] Iron, as a non-toxic, inexpensive and earth abundant metal, is an ideal candidate for the synthesis of new catalysts. Indeed, many Fe complexes have been investigated for the ROP of cyclic esters [16] although deserving less attention than, e. g., Zn or Al. Many different ancillary ligands, especially polydentate ligands with N and/or O donors, have been screened for the synthesis of iron complexes of different geometries and coordination numbers, resulting in more or less efficient ROP catalysts. For example, tetra-coordinated (hybrid-guanidine)FeCl2 complexes were recently reported as highly active catalysts for the ROP in bulk of technical grade rac-LA or recrystallized l-LA at 150 °C, rivaling with Sn(Oct)2 under the same conditions [17]. Penta-coordinated or hexa-coordinated iron complexes bearing tridentate and tetradentate ligands were generally less active [6] although penta-coordinated LFeN(SiMe3)2 (L = tripodal pyridyl-amino-phenolate ligands) were recently shown to behave as efficient and stereoselective catalysts for the ROP of rac-LA at room temperature. Examples of iron ROP catalysts with low coordination number are rare: e. g. a three-coordinated (β-diiminate)Fe(O‑tert-Bu) was reported as an active catalyst for the ROP of lactide and caprolactone at room temperature [18]. More recently, heteroleptic (amidomethylpyridine)FeIIN(SiMe3)2 complexes were synthesized, but the expected three-coordinated complexes could not be isolated, while the corresponding tetra-coordinated pyridine adducts were crystallized and tested in the ROP of l-LA, resulting in good activities at 50 °C in toluene, which were better than those of the in situ prepared pyridine-free species [19]. We have previously reported three-coordinated Zn(II) complexes bearing pyridylamido ligands with bulky substituents at both the amido and the ortho-pyridine moieties as efficient catalysts for the ROP of l-LA and ε-caprolactone (CL) [13]. We have now used the same class of ligands to synthesize stable and isolable three-coordinated [N,N −]FeIIN(SiMe3)2, which have been tested as catalysts for the ROP of LA and CL under both mild and high-temperature industrially relevant conditions. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of the pyridylamido Fe(II) complexes Fe(II) complexes 1, 2 were synthesized by allowing to react the pyridylamido proligands (which were prepared according to previously reported procedures) [20] with 1 equiv. of Fe[N(SiMe 3)2]2 in benzene at room temperature (see Scheme 1 ). The solvent and the HN(SiMe3)2 byproduct were removed under reduced pressure, affording orange microcrystalline solids, which were washed with hexane (yields ≈ 60 %). Recrystallization from hexane at −20 °C resulted in orange crystals, among which single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were selected and analyzed. The X-ray molecular structures of 1 (CCDC deposition number 2,307,496) and 2 (CCDC deposition number 2,307,486) are displayed in Fig. 1 (ORTEP were drawn using OLEX2) [21]. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 1 . The crystal structures confirm the formation of heteroleptic mononuclear [N,N]FeII[N(SiMe 3)2]2 complexes. Crystals of 1 show a triclinic unit cell belonging to the centrosymmetric space group P 1 ¯ , while the Fe(II) complex 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic unit cell in the centrosymmetric space group P21/n. Both X-ray molecular structures show a Fe mononuclear species with the Fe atom coordinated to the two nitrogen atoms of the pyridylamido ligand and the nitrogen atom of the bis(trimethylsilyl)amide moiety. The Fe atoms in 1 and 2 display a slightly distorted trigonal planar geometry around the three-coordinated Fe(II) ion. Considering the mean plane defined by N1, N2 and N3 atoms, Fe atom in complex 1 deviates by −0.1079(3) Å and in complex 2 by −0.1509(5) Å. The aromatic moieties in both compounds are almost perpendicular to the ligand plane. Particularly, the methyl substituted aromatic moieties are tilted by 62.07(12)° in 1 and 65.70(12)° in 2, whereas the isopropyl substituted aromatic moieties are tilted by 68.71(12)° and 79.32(12)°, respectively. A similar coordination mode was observed in the corresponding pyridylamido Zn(II) complex [13]. To compare the coordination geometry of 1 and 2 with other three-coordinated Fe(II) complexes, a total of 30 high quality (R<10 %) and not disordered crystal structures of β-diketiminate Fe complexes were extracted from the Cambridge Structural Database [22] considering the bond distances and angles at the Fe(II) atom and the distance between the Fe atom and the mean plane defined by the coordinating heteroatoms. From this analysis emerges that the mean angle value between the nitrogen atoms of the β-diketiminate and the Fe atoms is 94.3°, which is larger with respect to the N1–Fe1–N2 angles in 1 (82.5°) and 2 (81.3°), while the other two mean value angles involving the third coordinating atom are 130.7° and 134.1° The mean values of the Fe-N bonds of β-diketiminate Fe complexes obtained from the CSD analysis is 1.99 Å, to be compared with the shorter Fe-N1 (amido) bonds and the longer Fe-N2 (pyridino) bonds in 1 and 2. The mean distance between the Fe atom and the mean plane defined by the three coordinating atoms is 0.07 Å indicating a less distorted trigonal planar geometry compared to the complexes 1 and 2. The complexes were also analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy in benzene-d6: the spectra showed typically paramagnetically shifted peaks for a high spin Fe(II) d6 complex, ranging from δ = −116 to 79 ppm (complex 1) (Fig. S1) and δ= −83 to 133 ppm (complex 2) (Fig. S2) In the 1H NMR spectra, the disappearance of the signal at δ = 61.1 ppm assigned to the SiMe 3 protons of the iron precursor Fe[N(SiMe 3)2]2 and the broad signals at δ = 9.7 ppm for complex 1 and δ = 25.9 ppm for complex 2 which can be attributed to the protons of the methyl groups bonded to silicon atoms, as suggested for similar compounds [19] confirm the formation of heteroleptic complexes. The stability of our three-coordinated Fe(II) species at variance with the reported instability of analogous complexes, for which only tetracoordinated adducts with an additional pyridine ligand could be isolated [19] can be reasonably attributed to the increased steric hindrance at the pyridine moiety (a 2,6-dimethylphenyl substituent vs. a H or Me in the previously reported complexes). 2.2 Ring opening polymerization of l-lactide Complexes 1 and 2 were tested in the ROP of l-lactide (Scheme 2 ) under different conditions (see Table 2 ). Preliminary tests carried out at room temperature in CH2Cl2 solutions ([Fe] = 5 mM) using 200:1 monomer to catalyst ratio did not afford any polymer using cat. 1 (run 1) while a monomer conversion of 12 % in 10 min was achieved by complex 2 (run 2). Since it is known that the bulky -N(SiMe3)2 is a poor initiating group, the addition of 1 equiv. of iPrOH as co-initiator under the same conditions resulted in much better activities: conversions of 55 % for 1 (run 3) and 90 % for 2 (run 4) were obtained in 5 min. A good control of molecular weight was achieved by 2, while 1 afforded a polymer with a higher dispersity (1.8), possibly owing to a lower catalyst stability in dichloromethane solution (a color change from dark orange to purple was observed in few minutes for 1, while no visual change occurred for 2 bearing a CH3 substituent on the C-bridging the pyridine and the amido moieties). Following the suggestion of a reviewer, we tested catalyst 2, having a chiral center on the bridge, in the ROP of rac-LA (run 5), resulting in the production of atactic PLA (Fig. S5). The kinetics of the ROP of l-LA promoted by complex 2 and 1 equiv. of i PrOH at 25 °C was studied by NMR monitoring the polymerization of 200 equiv. of l-LA. Plot of ln([LA]0/[LA]t) versus time shows a first-order dependence on the concentration of lactide, with an apparent propagation rate constant of 1.2 × 10−2 s−1 (see Fig. 2 ). Interestingly, the latter apparent propagation rate constant is more than 1 order of magnitude larger than that measured for a previously reported similar Zn(II) catalyst [13]. The higher activity of a three-coordinate Fe(II) complex vs. a three-coordinate Zn(II) complex could be ascribed to the higher electronic and coordinative unsaturation of the Fe(II) species. Catalysts 1 and 2 were then tested at larger monomer/catalysts ratios in solution of toluene at 50 °C using [Fe] = 2.5 mM. Under these conditions both catalysts are extremely active, resulting in almost complete conversions of 500 or 1000 equiv. of l-LA in 1 - 2 min (see runs 6–8), interestingly affording polymers with very high molecular weight (Mn up to 192 kDa, run 8). As addressed in a previous paper [23] the industrial process to produce PLA operates at much higher T (190 °C) and larger monomer/catalyst molar ratios (≈ 104), while most of the reported catalysts have been tested only under milder conditions. In this respect, we have recently shown that, screening several Zn catalysts of the same class, the activity trends at room temperature and at 190 °C can be very different [23]. Thus, we tested the new Fe catalysts in melt monomer at 190 °C using technical grade l-LA, gradually increasing the [LA]/[Fe] and [BnOH]/[Fe] ratios to adjust the molecular weights of the obtained polymer and proof the stability of catalysts in immortal conditions. Both complexes resulted highly active also under these industrially relevant conditions: e. g. using 1000 equiv. of unpurified technical grade l-LA and 1 - 2 equiv. of benzyl alcohol co-initiator, high conversions were achieved in 3–4 min (after that time stirring became difficult due the viscosity of the reaction mixtures). Increasing the amount of alcohol or the monomer / catalyst ratio resulted in lower polymerization activities (see runs 13–16). The polymerization performed using BnOH:Fe 5:1 molar ratio showed a good control under these “immortal conditions”, as indicated by the excellent agreement between the molecular weights obtained by GPC analysis and those calculated theoretically (see runs 13–14). 2.3 Ring opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone The Fe complexes 1 and 2 were also tested in the ROP of ε-caprolactone (Scheme 3 ) in CH2Cl2 at 25 °C, using [Fe] = 5 mM and [ε-CL]:[Fe]:[ROH] = 200:1:1(Table 3 ). Monomer conversions > 90 % were achieved over 90 min, producing polymers with narrow polydispersity and a good agreement between the molecular weights measured by GPC analysis and those calculated theoretically (see runs 16–17). A kinetic study for the polymerization of CL by complex 2 and 1 eq. of iPrOH at 25 °C was performed by NMR analysis as above described for the ROP of l-LA. Plot of ln([LA]0/[LA]t) versus time shows a first-order dependence on the concentration of ε-caprolactone, with an apparent propagation rate constant of 5.6 × 10−4 s − 1 (see Fig. 3 ). The Fe catalysts resulted much more active at higher temperatures: polymerizations carried out in toluene at 50° using [ε-CL]:[Fe]:[ROH] = 500:1:1 resulted in excellent performance (see runs 18–19). Remarkably, both Fe catalysts were able to convert 500 equiv. of ε-CL in 1 min at 100 °C in toluene (TOF's ≈ 30,000 h−1, runs 20–21) and in 30 s at 130 °C without solvent (TOF's ≈ 60,000 h−1, runs 22–23). 2.4 Block copolymerization of l-LA, d-LA, rac-LA by sequential monomer addition Blends of isotactic poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA) and poly(D-lactic acid) (PDLA) are commercially produced for applications requiring better thermal properties, since they afford a stereocomplex phase with Tm up to 230 °C. An alternative approach proposed in the literature involves the synthesis of stereo-di (or multi-) block copolymers, either from rac-LA using suitable stereoselective catalysts [6] or by sequential addition of lactide enantiomers to living and very active catalysts [11–13]. Considering the controlled nature and high rate of the polymerization promoted by the pyridylamido Fe(II) catalyst 2 under mild conditions, we targeted the synthesis of stereoblock copolymers by one-pot sequential addition of l-LA, d-LA and rac-LA (see Scheme 4 and Table 4 ). PLLA-b-PDLA diblock copolymers of different lengths (runs 24 and 25), retaining a high block steric purity, as confirmed by HD-1H NMR analysis (see Fig. 4 ), were easily obtained from sequential addition of l-LA and d-LA at room temperature and in reasonably short times. Similarly, PLLA-b-PDLA-b-PLLA three-block copolymers were obtained by sequential addition of l-LA, d -LA, and l-LA (runs 26 and 27). All the stereoblock copolymers have Tm ranging between 209 and 214 °C, well above the Tm of homochiral isotactic PLA (178 °C) confirming the formation of the stereocomplex crystalline phase [12,13]. Finally, sequential addition of l-LA, rac-LA and d-LA resulted in a PLLA-b-PDLLA-b-PDLA three block copolymer having two crystalline end blocks and an amorphous middle block, displaying a Tm = 199 °C (run 28). 2.5 Copolymerization of l-LA and ε-CL Block copolymerization of ε-CL and l-LA could also be achieved by properly selecting the order of monomer addition (Table 5 ): in fact, a polymerization run using 10 μmol of catalyst 2, 1 equiv. of iPrOH and 200 equiv. of ε-CL in CH2Cl2 at 25 °C followed after 30 min by the addition of 200 equiv. of l-LA resulted in the production of a di-block copolymer (Scheme 5 ), as indicated by a DOSY NMR experiment showing that PLA and PCL have the same diffusion coefficient (Fig. S20). Also, GPC analysis showed a monomodal molecular weight distribution and a Mn in agreement with the theoretical molecular weight calculated for the copolymer (Fig. S21). Accordingly, a one-pot synthesis of three block PLLA-b-PCL-b-PLLA could be achieved by ROP of ε-CL using catalyst 2 and benzenedimethanol as initiator in CH2Cl2 (Scheme 5), affording a di‑hydroxy terminated PCL in 7 min, followed by the addition of a l-LA. The formation of a copolymer consisting of two crystalline PLA end blocks and a low Tg CL middle block was also confirmed by a DOSY NMR experiment (Fig. 5 ) and GPC analysis (Fig. S22). On the contrary, when the reverse sequence of monomers addition was used only PLLA homopolymer was produced, while ε-CL did not react at all. The same finding was frequently observed in previous literature [13,24,25] and it was attributed to the much higher coordination ability of LA. Accordingly, attempted copolymerization of equimolar amounts of l-LA and ε-CL using catalyst 2 and 1 equiv. of BnOH at 50 °C in toluene resulted in the production of PLA only. Some copolymerization could be obtained under harsher conditions, i.e., at 130 or 190 °C without solvent, but quantitative conversion was achieved only for l-LA, while conversion of ε-CL did not exceed 20–25%. Under the latter conditions, copolymerization is possible owing to transesterification reactions [26], as confirmed by 13C NMR analysis, showing a resonance at δ 171 ppm, diagnostic of the triad having a half-lactide (i. e. a single lactic acid) unit between two ε-CL units (Fig. S12). 3 Conclusion Rational design of chelating [N,N]− pyridylamido ligands introducing bulky 2,6-dialkylphenyl substituents at both the amido and the ortho-pyridine moieties allowed the isolation and full characterization of stable three-coordinated heteroleptic [N,N]FeIIN(SiMe3)2 complexes. The complexes were tested as catalysts for the ROP of l-lactide: after activation with 1 equiv. of alcohol an excellent polymerization performance was achieved both in solution at 25–50 °C and in solvent-free conditions at higher temperature and higher monomer/catalyst ratio. A very good performance was also achieved in the ROP of ε-caprolactone in solution at 50–100 °C as well as in solvent-free conditions at 130 °C. Owing to the high activity and the living character of the Fe(II) catalysts, sequential addition at room temperature of l-lactide and d-lactide resulted in the one-pot synthesis of PLLA-b-PDLA diblock copolymers and PLLA-b-PDLA-b-PLLA three-block copolymers, displaying the high melting temperature which is the fingerprint of the stereocomplex crystalline phase. Also, a three-block PLLA-b-PDLLA-b-PDLA was obtained using rac-lactide in the second addition step. Similarly, diblock PCL-b-PLA and three-block PLA-b-PCL-b-PLA were synthesized by ROP of CL as the first monomer in the presence of either benzyl alcohol or benzenedimethanol, followed by the addition of l-LA. On the contrary, no polymerization of CL could be obtained in the presence of LA at room temperature. Future work will address the application of these highly active Fe(II) catalysts for the polymerization of poorly reactive monomers, such as 6-membered lactones and macrolactones. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General All manipulations involving air and moisture-sensitive compounds were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere in a Braun Labmaster glovebox or using Schlenk techniques. Glassware was dried in an oven at 120 °C overnight and exposed to vacuum–nitrogen cycles. All solvents were dried as follows: toluene was refluxed over metallic sodium, dichloromethane was refluxed over CaH2, benzene and hexane were refluxed over sodium–benzophenone; they were distilled under nitrogen before use. Deuterated solvents were purchased from Aldrich and stored in the glovebox over 4 A molecular sieves before use. l-Lactide was purified by crystallization from dry toluene. ε-Caprolactone was stirred with CaH2 for 24 h at room temperature and then distilled under reduced pressure. Fe[N(SiMe 3)2]2 was synthesized according to the literature [27]. All other chemicals were commercially available and used as received unless otherwise stated. NMR spectra were recorded using either a Bruker Advance 300, or 400 or a Bruker 600 MHz Ascend 3 HD spectrometer. Chemical shifts (δ) are expressed as parts per million and coupling constants (J) in hertz. 1H NMR spectra are referenced using the residual solvent peak at δ 7.26 for CDCl3, d 5.32 for CD2Cl2 and d 7.16 for C6D6. 13C NMR spectra are referenced using the residual solvent peak at d 77.22 for CDCl3, d 53.84 for CD2Cl2 and d 128.06 for C6D6. The molecular weights (Mn and Mw) and the molecular weight distribution (Mw/ Mn) of polymer samples were measured by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) using Agilent 1260 Infinity Series GPC (ResiPore 3 μm, 300 × 7.5 mm, 1.0 mL min-1, UV (250 nm) and refractive index (RI, PLGPC 220) detector. All measurements were performed with THF or CHCl3 as the eluent at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min at 35 °C. Monodisperse poly(styrene) polymers were used as calibration standards. The instrument was calibrated for temperature and enthalpy by a high purity indium (156.60 °C, 28.45 J g−1) standard. 4.2 Synthesis of Fe complex 1 In an Mbraun glovebox, a solution of the pyridylamino proligand (188 mg, 0.5 mmol) in benzene (2 mL) was added dropwise into a solution of Fe[N(SiMe 3)2]2 (190 mg, 0.5 mmol) in benzene (1 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the solid residue was washed twice using dry hexane to obtain an orange powder (yield 165 mg, 56 %). 4.3 Synthesis of complex 2 In an Mbraun glovebox, a solution of the pyridylamino proligand (107 mg, 0.28 mmol) in benzene (2 mL) was added dropwise into a solution of Fe[N(SiMe 3)2]2 (104 mg, 0.28 mmol) in benzene (1 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The solvent was removed in vacuo and the solid residue was washed twice using dry hexane to obtain an orange powder (yield 104 mg, 63 %) 4.4 Characterization of complexes 1 and 2 1H NMR spectra of 1 and 2 were recorded in C6D6, showing typically paramagnetically shifted peaks for a high spin Fe(II) d6 complex, ranging from δ = −83 to 135 ppm for complex 1 (Fig. S1) and δ= −116 to 79 ppm for complex 2 (Fig. S2). 4.5 X-ray crystallography Crystals of the compounds 1 and 2 suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by slow evaporation, dissolving 120 mg of the compounds in hexane (10 mL). For both compounds, orange prismatic single crystals were selected and mounted on a cryoloop with paratone oil and measured at 100 K with a Bruker D8 QUEST diffractometer equipped with a PHOTON detector using Cu-Kα radiation (λ= 1.54178 Å). Data indexing was performed using APEX3 [28]. Data integration and reduction were performed using SAINT [29]. Absorption correction was performed by multi-scan method in SADABS [30]. The structures were solved using SHELXS [31] and refined by means of full matrix least-squares based on F2 using the program SHELXL [32]. For both crystal structures, non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically and included in structure factors calculations but not refined. Relevant crystallographic data are reported in Table 6 . 4.6 Homo-polymerization of l-Lactide and ε-caprolactone In a typical homopolymerization run, a magnetically stirred reactor vessel was charged with a solution of the monomer in the selected solvent to which the alcohol (either isopropanol, at 25 °C or benzyl alcohol, at higher temperatures) and then the Fe catalyst was added. After the prescribed time, an aliquot of the crude material was sampled and quenched in wet CH2Cl2 or CHCl3. The sample was subjected to monomer conversion determination, which was monitored by integration of monomer versus polymer in the 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. S4). The reaction was quenched by exposing to air and adding wet CH2Cl2 or CHCl3. The crude product was precipitated in methanol (for l-LA) or hexane (for ε-CL). The obtained polymer was collected by filtration and further dried in an oven at 60 °C i. vac. for 16 h. The polymers were characterized by 1H NMR and GPC analysis. 4.7 Block copolymerization of lactide isomers In a glove box, to a CH2Cl2 solution of l-LA were added iPrOH and catalyst 2; the reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at room temperature. An aliquot of the reaction mixture was sampled to determine the monomer conversion by 1H NMR. After a proper time, d-LA or rac-LA was added and allowed to react for a proper time, after which again l-LA (or d-LA) was added. The work up of the reaction mixtures was carried out as described above. The products were characterized by 1H NMR, homo-decoupled 1H NMR (Figs. S6–S10), Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Figs. S13–S17) and GPC analysis. 4.8 Block copolymerization of l-Lactide and ε-caprolactone In a glove box, to a CH2Cl2 solution of ε-CL either benzyl alcohol or 1,4-benzenedimethanol and catalyst 2 were added sequentially; the reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at room temperature for the prescribed time, and then l-LA was added. An aliquot of the reaction mixture was sampled and quenched in wet CDCl3 to determine the conversion of each monomer as described above. The work up of the reaction mixtures was carried out as described above. The products were characterized by 1H NMR, DSC (Figs. S18, S19) and GPC Analysis. Attempted copolymerization using the reverse sequence of monomer addition resulted in the production of PLA only. coredata.dc:description: Two Fe(II) complexes bearing chelating monoanionic [N,N]− pyridylamido ligands with bulky 2,6-dialkylphenyl substituents at both the amido and the ortho-pyridine moieties were synthesized and characterized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the formation of heteroleptic mononuclear [N,N]FeIIN(SiMe3)2 three-coordinated complexes. The two complexes were tested as catalysts for the Ring Opening Polymerization (ROP) of l-lactide (L-LA) and ε-caprolactone (CL) in the presence of 1 equiv. of alcohol co-initiator, resulting in high activity under both mild conditions (in solution at room temperature and low monomer/catalyst ratio) and more industrially relevant conditions (higher temperature and high monomer/catalyst ratio). The high activity and living character of the Fe(II) catalysts allowed the synthesis of stereo-multiblock polylactides by one-pot sequential addition of l-LA, d-LA and rac-LA at room temperature and in short reaction times, as well as the synthesis of di-block PCL-b-PLLA and three-block PLLA-b-PCL-b-PLLA copolymers by a similar approach.
